    Breaking Degeneracy with the Spin-Orbit Interaction

    Background

    In quantum mechanics, the spin-orbit interaction is the interaction of the spin of a particle with its orbital motion . It is a well-known effect that lifts the degeneracy of the one-electron energy levels in atoms, molecules, and crystals.

    The nonrelativistic Schrodinger equation is used to find the electronic band structure of crystal lattices. Since there are no relativistic corrections (i.e. no spin terms in the Hamiltonian), each of the bands is doubly degenerate - both the spin up and spin down electrons have the same energy. However, if we introduce a correction in the Schrodinger equation that involves the spin of the particle, we see that these degenerate bands split apart. The spin-orbit interaction is one such correction; it has the form:

    Conclusions

    These relationships are interesting, but why do we care?

    Suppose I want to use perturbation theory to study the splitting of the electronic band structure as I mentioned above. Choosing a basis in or is not a good idea in this case. The and operators do not commute with the spin-orbit Hamiltonian, and thus, will not make good basis states for degenerate perturbation theory. However, choosing a basis in , , , or would work out very well. These operators commute with the spin-orbit Hamiltonian, and so they would be good choices for degenerate perturbation theory.

    Additionally, since these operators commute with the spin-orbit Hamiltonian, they are constants of motion - quantities that are conserved throughout the evolution of the object. Thus, they are particularly interesting to study in this system.
